qas.question: What does the first amendment to the US Constitution state?

answers.text: "Congress shall make no law respecting an establishment of religion, or prohibiting the free exercise thereof"

qas.question: What is the first part of the First Amendment know as?
What is the last part of the sentence of the First Amendment known as?
What do the two clauses of the First Amendment for the basis of?

answers.text: the Supreme Court's interpretations of the "separation of church and state" doctrine.

qas.question: What are citizens of the United States free to embrace or reject as they choose?

plausible_answers.text: Congress shall make no law respecting an establishment of religion, or prohibiting the free exercise thereof

qas.question: What does the second amendment to the US Constitution state?
What is the second part of the First Amendment know as?
What is the first part of the sentence of the First Amendment known as?

plausible_answers.text: Supreme Court's interpretations of the "separation of church and state"

qas.question: What do the four clauses of the First Amendment for the basis of?
What are citizens of the United States not free to embrace or reject as they choose?

context: The first amendment to the US Constitution states <a0_0>"<b5_0>Congress shall make no law respecting an establishment of religion, or prohibiting the free exercise thereof<b5_0/>"<a0_0/> The two parts, known as the <a1_0>"<b6_0>establishment clause<b6_0/>"<a1_0/> and the <a2_0>"<b7_0>free exercise clause<b7_0/>"<a2_0/> respectively, form the textual basis for <a3_0>the <b8_0>Supreme Court's interpretations of the "separation of church and state"<b8_0/> doctrine.<a3_0/> Three central concepts were derived from the 1st Amendment which became America's doctrine for church-state separation: no coercion in religious matters, no expectation to support a religion against one's will, and religious liberty encompasses all religions. In sum, citizens are free to embrace or reject <a4_0>a <b9_0>faith<b9_0/><a4_0/>, any support for religion - financial or physical - must be voluntary, and all religions are equal in the eyes of the law with no special preference or favoritism.
